newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk miller's flour sale to Iraq hits customs snag.
newsitem.headline: Turk miller's flour sale to Iraq hits customs snag.

text.p: A Turkish flour miller and trading company, Besler, said on Wednesday its pledge to sell Iraq 14,000 tonnes of wheat flour was being hampered by formalities at customs in southeast Turkey.
"The customs centres near our storehouses in the southeast don't approve our export documents and that delays our sales," said Cemal Besler, general manager of the company.
"Customs officials show no reason for their attitude despite promises in our favour by (State) Minister Ayfer Yilmaz and senior customs officials in Ankara," he told Reuters.
He said other companies with deals of "at least 50,000 tonnes of flour" were in the same situation.
Customs officials were not available for comment.

The deals were to be carried out under normal humanitarian sales to Iraq under U.N. auspices, not under the continuing oil-for-food deal allowing Iraq to sell oil worth $2 billion to buy food and medicine.
"Our flour deal was priced at $330 per tonne and was going to be sent to Mosul in Iraq," Besler said.
Besler said customs offices in Nusaybin, at Turkey's border with Syria, and Cizre, near the Iraqi and Syrian borders, were not approving their export documents.
"The office in Silopi (near Iraq) approves them but its far away from our storehouses, which are in Nusaybin," he said.
The government allows duty-free wheat imports by millers if they use the wheat to produce flour for export purposes only.
But if exporters do not document their sales, they cannot import wheat under the duty-free scheme.
Besler said the millers would have to pay fines if they failed to deliver the shipments to Iraq on time.
